thread.title: Rescue patrol marks five years since tragic death
thread.title_full: Rescue patrol marks five years since tragic death | UTV - ITV News

author: itv.com
title: Rescue patrol marks five years since tragic death
text:
A rescue patrol which was set up following the tragic death of a young Belfast man has come together to remember his fifth anniversary.
The Community Rescue Service was established after 20-year-old Joby Murphy drowned in the River Lagan after a night out.
For his dad Joe, the memories of that night are still so fresh.
“I got a knock on the door, it was the police. They said you better come down to the weir with us, and I said what for – they said ‘we think your son is in the river’, I just couldn’t think,” he told UTV.
“They took me down in the car and I stood on the old bridge in the freezing cold and it was just so unreal.”
Play video At the weekend his family, friends and volunteers came to remember him five years on.
Some of those who searched for Joby stood side-by-side with his loved ones.
His loved ones had to wait an agonising 31 days before his body was recovered.
It was the Community Rescue Service - using specialist equipment - that found him.
Since then it has patrolled the waters 500 times.
It was only after Joby's death that the Community Rescue Service set up weekend patrols in Belfast.
Since then the volunteers have saved hundreds of lives.
Paul Stitt, a volunteer with Community Rescue Service, told UTV: “You find [people] on the bridges, you find them sitting about, we would go over and talk to them and over that period of time, anybody we’ve come into contact with, we’ve actually saved. Nobody has gone into the water while we’ve been here and not come back out alive.
“There’s always somebody else that needs saved or helped and that’s why I come down here every week.”
It’s that legacy which Joby's family clings to, as his dad explains: “It makes you feel better that something’s good has been done out of the tragedy that happened to Joby and hopefully, that sort of tragedy will never happen again on the River Lagan.”
 rescue Northern Ireland
